anns.prefix: Graphical Abstract  Highlights •A minimal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis•Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and
anns.postfix: is mediated by an NRPS enzyme•A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual self-resistance system•MinD functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo A minimal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS enzyme A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual self-resistance system MinD functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo Biotechnology; Microbial Biotechnology; Systems Biology Subject Areas Published: December 20, 2019 Introduction Introduction The C-nucleoside antibiotics (Figure 1) constitute an important sub-group of microbial natural products with unusual structural features and diverse biological activities (Isono, 1988, Maffioli et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: Less typically, minimycin (
anns.postfix: , also called oxazinomycin) is produced by diverse bacterial strains, either Streptomyces sp. or Pseudomonas sp., and shows prominent antimicrobial activities against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria (Kusakabe et al., 1972, Tymiak et al., 1984).

anns.prefix: Less typically, minimycin (MIN, also called
anns.postfix: ) is produced by diverse bacterial strains, either Streptomyces sp. or Pseudomonas sp., and shows prominent antimicrobial activities against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria (Kusakabe et al., 1972, Tymiak et al., 1984).

is structurally similar to pseudouridine, a modified nucleoside that is found abundantly in tRNA (Li et al., 2016).

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: molecule has a unique structural feature in which a 1,3-oxazine 2,4-dione ring and a ribosyl sugar are linked via a C-glycoside bond (Sasaki et al., 1972) (Figure 1).

anns.prefix: Previous metabolic labeling studies have shown that the ribosyl portion of
anns.postfix: derives directly from D-ribose (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1975, Isono and Suhadolnik, 1977), and C-6, C-5, and C-4 of the oxazine ring arise from the corresponding C-3, C-4, and C-5 of L-glutamate (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1977).

anns.prefix: Metabolic feeding experiments by Isono et al. showed that the C-2 of
anns.postfix: is derived from carbon dioxide (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1975).

anns.prefix: Concomitant chemical synthesis of
anns.postfix: was also achieved, with the finding that the synthetic form of MIN shares identical biological features with that from microbial source (De Bernardo and Weigele, 1977).

(Figure 1) is a bipyridyl pigment that was first documented as a microbial natural product in the 1960s (Kuhn et al., 1965), and later discovered to be produced by surprisingly diverse microbes (Heumann et al., 1968, Starr et al., 1966).

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: biosynthetic gene cluster was initially reported from Dickeya dadantii (formerly known as Erwinia chrysanthemi), and it was revealed that it has important roles in pathogenicity and self-resistance to oxidative stress (Reverchon et al., 2002).

anns.prefix: The gene for
anns.postfix: biosynthesis was later identified from diverse Streptomyces strains (Novakova et al., 2010, Pait et al., 2017, Yu et al., 2013).

anns.prefix: A single module non-ribosomal peptide synthetase (NRPS), which selectively recognizes L-glutamine as the starter substrate, was necessary for
anns.postfix: biosynthesis (Brown et al., 2017, Takahashi et al., 2007).

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: NRPS gene was subsequently engineered as a promising tool for synthetic biology purposes, either for natural product discovery (Olano et al., 2014) or as a reporter system (Muller et al., 2012, Rezuchova et al., 2018, Xie et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: More recently, Ankanahalli et al. have created a transgenic blue rose by introduction of a bacterial
anns.postfix: biosynthesis gene (idgS) and a phosphopantetheinyl transferase gene (sfp) from surfactin biosynthesis (Nanjaraj Urs et al., 2019).

anns.prefix: In the present study, we address the biosynthesis of C-nucleoside
anns.postfix: and indigoidine in Streptomyces hygroscopicus JCM 4712.

anns.prefix: In the present study, we address the biosynthesis of C-nucleoside MIN and
anns.postfix: in Streptomyces hygroscopicus JCM 4712.

anns.prefix: We report that a minimal 5-gene cluster is essential for
anns.postfix: biosynthesis and show that the divergent biosynthesis of MIN and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS, MinA. Moreover, we reveal that the N-terminal phosphatase domain of MinC (called MinCN), the MinD uracil phosphoribosyltransferase, and the MinT transporter are safeguard enzymes, which collaboratively constitute an unusual self-resistance system, in which MinD likely employs an unprecedented substrate-competition strategy for self-resistance by increasing the UMP pool in vivo.

anns.postfix: pathway expands current understanding regarding natural product biosynthesis and self-resistance.

anns.prefix: Earlier studies reported that
anns.postfix: production affects the pathogenicity of the plant pathogen Dickeya dadantii (Reverchon et al., 2002).

anns.prefix: Divergent Biosynthesis of
anns.postfix: and Indigoidine Is Mediated by an NRPS-Associated Assembly Line Divergent Biosynthesis of MIN and Indigoidine Is Mediated by an NRPS-Associated Assembly Line Divergent Biosynthesis of MIN and Indigoidine Is Mediated by an NRPS-Associated Assembly Line Previous isotopic feeding experiments had showed that L-glutamate is incorporated into the oxazine ring of MIN (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1977, Suhadolnik and Reichenbach, 1981), whereas its ribosyl moiety is from D-ribose (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1975).

biosynthesis is confirmed to be initiated by MinA, which specifically selects L-glutamine as substrate, and the tethered amino acid is then dehydrogenated under strict and precise stereospecificity/regiospecificity at the C2-C3 positions by the oxidase domain (Ox domain).

anns.prefix: Graphical Abstract  Highlights •A minimal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis•Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and indigoidine is mediated by an
anns.postfix: enzyme•A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual self-resistance system•MinD functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo A minimal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS enzyme A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual self-resistance system MinD functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo Biotechnology; Microbial Biotechnology; Systems Biology Subject Areas Published: December 20, 2019 Introduction Introduction The C-nucleoside antibiotics (Figure 1) constitute an important sub-group of microbial natural products with unusual structural features and diverse biological activities (Isono, 1988, Maffioli et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: We report that a minimal 5-gene cluster is essential for MIN biosynthesis and show that the divergent biosynthesis of MIN and indigoidine is mediated by an
anns.postfix: , MinA. Moreover, we reveal that the N-terminal phosphatase domain of MinC (called MinCN), the MinD uracil phosphoribosyltransferase, and the MinT transporter are safeguard enzymes, which collaboratively constitute an unusual self-resistance system, in which MinD likely employs an unprecedented substrate-competition strategy for self-resistance by increasing the UMP pool in vivo.

anns.prefix: Graphical Abstract  Highlights •A minimal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis•Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS enzyme•A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual self-resistance system•
anns.postfix: functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo A minimal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS enzyme A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual self-resistance system MinD functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo Biotechnology; Microbial Biotechnology; Systems Biology Subject Areas Published: December 20, 2019 Introduction Introduction The C-nucleoside antibiotics (Figure 1) constitute an important sub-group of microbial natural products with unusual structural features and diverse biological activities (Isono, 1988, Maffioli et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: Less typically, minimycin (
anns.postfix: , also called oxazinomycin) is produced by diverse bacterial strains, either Streptomyces sp. or Pseudomonas sp., and shows prominent antimicrobial activities against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria (Kusakabe et al., 1972, Tymiak et al., 1984).

anns.prefix: It has also demonstrated antitumor activity against transplantable tumors (Kusakabe et al., 1972).Figure 1Chemical Structures of Representative C-Nucleoside Antibiotics and IndigoidineSeveral C-nucleoside antibiotics (
anns.postfix: , group I; pyrazofurin-formycin, group II; malayamycin-pseudouridimycin, group III) shown are deduced to employ distinct enzymatic logics for the assembly of the C-glycosidic bond.

is structurally similar to pseudouridine, a modified nucleoside that is found abundantly in tRNA (Li et al., 2016).

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: molecule has a unique structural feature in which a 1,3-oxazine 2,4-dione ring and a ribosyl sugar are linked via a C-glycoside bond (Sasaki et al., 1972) (Figure 1).

anns.prefix: Previous metabolic labeling studies have shown that the ribosyl portion of
anns.postfix: derives directly from D-ribose (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1975, Isono and Suhadolnik, 1977), and C-6, C-5, and C-4 of the oxazine ring arise from the corresponding C-3, C-4, and C-5 of L-glutamate (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1977).

anns.prefix: Metabolic feeding experiments by Isono et al. showed that the C-2 of
anns.postfix: is derived from carbon dioxide (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1975).

anns.prefix: Concomitant chemical synthesis of
anns.postfix: was also achieved, with the finding that the synthetic form of MIN shares identical biological features with that from microbial source (De Bernardo and Weigele, 1977).

anns.prefix: In the present study, we address the biosynthesis of C-nucleoside
anns.postfix: and indigoidine in Streptomyces hygroscopicus JCM 4712.

anns.prefix: We report that a minimal 5-gene cluster is essential for
anns.postfix: biosynthesis and show that the divergent biosynthesis of MIN and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS, MinA. Moreover, we reveal that the N-terminal phosphatase domain of MinC (called MinCN), the MinD uracil phosphoribosyltransferase, and the MinT transporter are safeguard enzymes, which collaboratively constitute an unusual self-resistance system, in which MinD likely employs an unprecedented substrate-competition strategy for self-resistance by increasing the UMP pool in vivo.

anns.prefix: To reconstitute
anns.postfix: activity in vitro, we over-expressed and purified the MinA protein from E. coli.

anns.prefix: The purified
anns.postfix: shows bright yellow color (Figures S4F and S4G), a typical feature of a flavin-dependent protein, as confirmed by LC-MS analysis (Figures S4H and S4I).

anns.prefix: Enzymatic assays with the recombinant
anns.postfix: produced an obvious blue color, implicating the production of indigoidine (Figures 3C and 3D), whose identity is further confirmed by LC-MS analysis (Figure S4J).

anns.prefix: Furthermore, the purified
anns.postfix: has only partial activity without an exogenous addition of FMN or Mg2+ (Figures 3D and S4K–S4M) and indicates the preference to relative low temperatures (18°C of all temperatures tested) (Figures S4N–S4P and S4R).

anns.prefix: Subsequently, we tested the substrate flexibility for
anns.postfix: against the unnatural isomer D-glutamine with negative result (Figures S4Q and S4R).

anns.prefix: These combined data substantially established that divergent biosynthesis of
anns.postfix: and indigoidine is mediated by the NRPS (MinA) pathway, in which the compound 1 is likely converted to indigoidine via a non-enzymatic spontaneous reaction.

anns.prefix: To investigate the enzymatic role of
anns.postfix: , it was over-expressed and purified from E. coli (Figure S7B), and the corresponding activity was determined in vitro.

anns.prefix: As anticipated, HPLC analysis showed that the
anns.postfix: reaction could generate a peak for UMP, corresponding to an authentic standard, which was absent from the negative control (Figure 4D).

anns.prefix: These results establish that
anns.postfix: functions as an UPRTase for the synthesis of UMP.

anns.prefix: Divergent Biosynthesis of
anns.postfix: and Indigoidine Is Mediated by an NRPS-Associated Assembly Line Divergent Biosynthesis of MIN and Indigoidine Is Mediated by an NRPS-Associated Assembly Line Divergent Biosynthesis of MIN and Indigoidine Is Mediated by an NRPS-Associated Assembly Line Previous isotopic feeding experiments had showed that L-glutamate is incorporated into the oxazine ring of MIN (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1977, Suhadolnik and Reichenbach, 1981), whereas its ribosyl moiety is from D-ribose (Isono and Suhadolnik, 1975).

biosynthesis is confirmed to be initiated by MinA, which specifically selects L-glutamine as substrate, and the tethered amino acid is then dehydrogenated under strict and precise stereospecificity/regiospecificity at the C2-C3 positions by the oxidase domain (Ox domain).

anns.prefix: Graphical Abstract  Highlights •A minimal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis•Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS enzyme•A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual
anns.postfix: system•MinD functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo A minimal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS enzyme A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual self-resistance system MinD functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo Biotechnology; Microbial Biotechnology; Systems Biology Subject Areas Published: December 20, 2019 Introduction Introduction The C-nucleoside antibiotics (Figure 1) constitute an important sub-group of microbial natural products with unusual structural features and diverse biological activities (Isono, 1988, Maffioli et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: Less typically, minimycin (MIN, also called oxazinomycin) is produced by diverse bacterial strains, either Streptomyces sp. or Pseudomonas sp., and shows prominent
anns.postfix: activities against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria (Kusakabe et al., 1972, Tymiak et al., 1984).

anns.prefix: Indigoidine (Figure 1) is a bipyridyl
anns.postfix: that was first documented as a microbial natural product in the 1960s (Kuhn et al., 1965), and later discovered to be produced by surprisingly diverse microbes (Heumann et al., 1968, Starr et al., 1966).

anns.prefix: The indigoidine biosynthetic gene cluster was initially reported from Dickeya dadantii (formerly known as Erwinia chrysanthemi), and it was revealed that it has important roles in pathogenicity and
anns.postfix: to oxidative stress (Reverchon et al., 2002).

anns.prefix: We report that a minimal 5-gene cluster is essential for MIN biosynthesis and show that the divergent biosynthesis of MIN and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS, MinA. Moreover, we reveal that the N-terminal phosphatase domain of MinC (called MinCN), the MinD uracil phosphoribosyltransferase, and the MinT transporter are safeguard enzymes, which collaboratively constitute an unusual
anns.postfix: system, in which MinD likely employs an unprecedented substrate-competition strategy for self-resistance by increasing the UMP pool in vivo.

anns.prefix: Limitations of the Study Limitations of the Study Limitations of the Study In this study, we have uncovered that divergent biosynthesis of MIN and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS enzyme and have demonstrated that an unprecedented collaborative
anns.postfix: system is employed for MIN biosynthesis.

anns.prefix: However, the precise mechanism of how MIN executes its
anns.postfix: role will require further study.

anns.prefix: Graphical Abstract  Highlights •A
anns.postfix: imal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis•Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS enzyme•A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual self-resistance system•MinD functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo A minimal 5-gene cluster (min) is essential for minimycin biosynthesis Divergent biosynthesis of minimycin and indigoidine is mediated by an NRPS enzyme A cascade of three safeguard enzymes constitutes the unusual self-resistance system MinD functions as the key safeguard enzyme by increasing the UMP pool in vivo Biotechnology; Microbial Biotechnology; Systems Biology Subject Areas Published: December 20, 2019 Introduction Introduction The C-nucleoside antibiotics (Figure 1) constitute an important sub-group of microbial natural products with unusual structural features and diverse biological activities (Isono, 1988, Maffioli et al., 2017).

anns.prefix: The second gene,
anns.postfix: , codes for an MFS transporter with high homology (79% identity) to SAMN05444521_6509 of Streptomyces sp. 3124.6 (Table 1), which is proposed to transport the antibiotic out of the producer cell.

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: product displays significant homology (74% identities in total) to IndC, an NRPS protein from Streptomyces chromofuscus ATCC 49982, and the domain architectures of both enzymes are highly matched (Table 1).

anns.prefix: Notably,
anns.postfix: encodes a 613-amino acid protein containing two domains, an N-terminal HAD phosphatase domain and the C-terminal DUF4243 domain with unassigned function.

anns.prefix: The indigoidine biosynthetic gene cluster was initially reported from Dickeya dadantii (formerly known as
anns.postfix: chrysanthemi), and it was revealed that it has important roles in pathogenicity and self-resistance to oxidative stress (Reverchon et al., 2002).

anns.prefix: The gene for indigoidine biosynthesis was later identified from diverse
anns.postfix: strains (Novakova et al., 2010, Pait et al., 2017, Yu et al., 2013).

anns.postfix: Identification of MIN Biosynthetic Gene Cluster from S. hygroscopicus JCM 4712 Identification of MIN Biosynthetic Gene Cluster from S. hygroscopicus JCM 4712 To identify the gene cluster responsible for MIN biosynthesis, the genome of S. hygroscopicus JCM 4712 was sequenced using the Illumina Hiseq 4000 method, which renders 8.8-Mb data (G + C content 70.31%) after assembly of clean reads.

MinR shows 87% identity to SAMN05444521_6508 of
anns.postfix: sp. 3124.6, which is likely a FadR family transcriptional regulator.

anns.prefix: The second gene, minT, codes for an MFS transporter with high homology (79% identity) to SAMN05444521_6509 of
anns.postfix: sp. 3124.6 (Table 1), which is proposed to transport the antibiotic out of the producer cell.

anns.prefix: The minA product displays significant homology (74% identities in total) to IndC, an NRPS protein from
anns.postfix: chromofuscus ATCC 49982, and the domain architectures of both enzymes are highly matched (Table 1).
